message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented by the patient are consistent with Tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by an anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum. This results in a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and overriding aorta. The bluish hue to the skin is due to cyanosis caused by the decrease in pulmonary blood flow. Squatting increases pulmonary blood flow, which relieves the symptoms temporarily.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum during embryonic development. This displacement causes a narrowing of the pulmonary artery (pulmonary stenosis), a ventricular septal defect, an overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. Squatting can increase systemic vascular resistance and decrease right-to-left shunting, improving symptoms temporarily. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral or partial development would not cause Tetralogy of Fallot, and the failure of the ductus arteriosus to obliterate would lead to patent ductus arteriosus, not Tetralogy of Fallot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blue coloration and relief with squatting suggests Tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum during development. This leads to a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The other options are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in this patient are suggestive of Tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum during embryologic development. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral can lead to transposition of the great arteries, while failure of the ductus arteriosus to obliterate can cause patent ductus arteriosus. Partial aorticopulmonary septum development can lead to persistent truncus arteriosus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by an anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum during fetal development. This displacement results in four abnormalities: a ventricular septal defect, an overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy. When the child squats, it increases systemic vascular resistance, which helps to decrease the right to left shunt and relieve the symptoms of cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the blue skin hue, suggest the patient has tetralogy of Fallot. Among the options, anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum is the cause of this condition. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral and partial aorticopulmonary septum development can also result in congenital heart defects but will not present with the same symptoms as tetralogy of Fallot. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to obliterate could lead to a patent ductus arteriosus, which also presents with different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest the patient has tetralogy of Fallot. This is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum during embryonic development, leading to a ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish hue when crying or agitated suggests cyanosis, and the relief of symptoms when squatting suggests a tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum during embryonic development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish hue indicated cyanosis, which suggests a cardiac defect. The ability to relieve symptoms by squatting is a characteristic of tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the aorticopulmonary septum. Therefore, the correct answer is (D).
